author: By Paulina Porizkova
title: Perfection Is a Dream. Real Beauty Has Flaws.
description: Digital magic can readily erase any blemish, any wrinkle, any evidence of authenticity and vulnerability. But where’s the beauty in that?
content: This personal reflection is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Exiting the Corridors of Power to Parties Spangled With Stars
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, December 4, 2023.
content: “Put a good dinner in front of him, and he was a very good talker about world politics, and he always took his time.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Coaston
title: This Conservative Wants to Change the Way Republicans Think About Economics
description: Americans are more pro-union than they’ve been in a long time. Jane Coaston interviews Oren Cass about his version of pro-worker conservatism.
content: Nearly half a million U.S. workers have gone on strike in 2023, demanding better workplace conditions and higher pay in some of the country’s most critical industries. Those workers — and the unions many of them belong to — have not received a great deal of support from most elected Republicans. The former South Carolina governor and presidential candidate Nikki Haley has proudly described herself as a “union buster,” saying in 2012 that unions “are not needed, not wanted and not welcome in the state of South Carolina.” Senator Tim Scott said at a September campaign event that striking workers should be fired, following the model of Ronald Reagan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: Netanyahu Corruption Trial Resumes, Adding to Israeli Leader’s Challenges
description: Courts in Israel suspended non-urgent cases after the Oct. 7 attacks, including the prime minister’s multiyear trial.
content: The corruption trial of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel resumed on Monday, bringing back into focus the legal and political challenges he faces even as he presides over the Israeli military’s war against Hamas in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer and Chris Cameron
title: Some Republicans Have a Blunt Message for Chris Christie: Drop Out
description: Several anti-Trump Republican donors and strategists are pushing Mr. Christie to end his presidential campaign and back Nikki Haley.
content: Chris Christie, the former governor of New Jersey, has traveled the world in his quest to stop Donald J. Trump’s march to the Republican nomination. In New Hampshire living rooms as well as the charred homes of Israeli families killed by Hamas, he has assailed the former president as being unfit to lead, antidemocratic and an aspiring dictator.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: State Police’s Female Troopers Warn Other Women Against Joining
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, December 5, 2023.
content: “Run the other way.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Warming meals that refresh and recharge
description: Caramelized cabbage and walnut pasta, vegetarian skillet chili and honey-glazed chicken with shallots for those precious, quiet December evenings.
content: I was sure I had plenty of time to prepare for the holidays as I flipped to the last page of my daughter’s corgi calendar — only to be confronted by a puppy in a Santa hat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: Spotify to Cut 1,500 Jobs After Spending Spree
description: The music streaming service has expanded into podcasting and audiobooks but found it difficult to turn a consistent profit.
content: Spotify said on Monday that it would cut nearly a fifth of its work force, its third round of layoffs so far this year, as it has struggled to become consistently profitable after spending aggressively to expand beyond music streaming into areas such as podcasting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Christobek
title: What to Know About Trump’s Civil Fraud Trial
description: Last week, bankers from Deutsche Bank testified on behalf of the former president, lending support to a central plank of his defense, while a gag order was reinstated against him.
content: Donald J. Trump’s defense lawyers will call his son and fellow defendant Eric Trump back to the witness stand this week, along with more expert witnesses to testify on the former president’s behalf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon and Joao Silva
title: This Building Was Deemed ‘Outright Inhumane.’ But They Say It’s Home.
description: Residents of a Johannesburg building know it is every bit as dangerous as one that burned in August, killing 77. But it’s a home, one they might not otherwise have, and a place to pursue their dreams and aspirations.
content: He had 40 years under his belt as a firefighter and inspector, but nothing could have prepared Boet Hamman for what he saw when he entered a cluster of dark buildings on Davies Street in downtown Johannesburg that about 600 people unlawfully called home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.7 Million Homes in California
description: A “boathouse” retreat in the hills of Los Angeles, a ranch house in Solvang and a 1964 home in Foster City.
content: This house in the hills above the Cahuenga Pass is one of the Boathouses, a group of homes built on small, steep lots. The architect, Harry Gesner, worked with Norwegian boatbuilders to create them, using glass walls and open floor plans to maximize space and natural light.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Israeli Troops Have Advanced Into Southern Gaza
description: Also, U.S. money for Ukraine will soon run out. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: Israel has begun an invasion of southern Gaza, the last section of the territory that had been under full Hamas control, with dozens of armored vehicles rolling closer to its main city and strikes pummeling urban areas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracey Tully and Hannah Yoon
title: The Police Force Where Female Officers Warn Other Women to Stay Away
description: The U.S. Justice Department is investigating claims of gender and racial discrimination at the New Jersey State Police.
content: After decades on the job, they had plenty of reasons to like working for the New Jersey State Police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Jonathan Majors Case Begins With a Debate: Was He an Abuser or a Victim?
description: Prosecutors said a March altercation came after years of bad behavior by the actor. His lawyer said he had been bloodied by the woman he is accused of assaulting.
content: Jonathan Majors, an actor whom Marvel had expected to anchor its tent-pole superhero franchise, manipulated, threatened and finally assaulted his ex-girlfriend inside a for-hire car in Manhattan, prosecutors said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced and Ephrat Livni
title: The Heat Rises at COP28
description: Dismissive comments by the president of the climate gathering raise questions about the host country’s commitment to addressing rising global temperatures.
content: Tensions are rising on Monday over contentious comments by Sultan Ahmed al Jaber, the oil executive and Emirati politician presiding over the COP28 climate summit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Grand Theft Auto VI Trailer Is Released to Eager Fans
description: Players will investigate every frame of the 90-second preview for evidence of what the open world’s next chapter might hold.
content: There was finally some relief for the large group of gamers that has been anticipating any official information about Grand Theft Auto VI, the next entry in the hit franchise developed by Rockstar Games.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian and Lara Jakes
title: White House Warns Ukraine Aid Is Running Out, Pressing Congress for More
description: The warning, in a letter to congressional leaders, comes as Republican support for funding Kyiv’s war effort is waning, and an emergency funding package is stalled in Congress.
content: The White House warned congressional leaders on Monday that the United States would run out of money to send weapons to Ukraine by year’s end, severely jeopardizing Kyiv’s ability to defend itself against Russia if lawmakers fail to approve emergency military aid soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Mair
title: Republicans Are Finding Out That ‘Pro-Life’ Means a Lot of Things to a Lot of People
description: How the G.O.P. can come up with a new approach to the politics of the issue.
content: Electoral results since the Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization decision should tell a lot of people in the Republican Party something they absolutely do not want to hear: Even rank-and-file G.O.P. voters are not as pro-life as we might have thought when Roe v. Wade was the law of the land.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wilson Wong
title: A New Literary Prize Taps a Jury Living Behind Bars
description: Over the next six months, inmates in prisons around the country will be able to debate and vote on the winner of a new book award — the Inside Literary Prize.
content: Over the next six months, a jury of inmates in prisons across six states will be able to read and debate books, then vote on the winner of a new award, the Inside Literary Prize.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas E. Ricks
title: How Different Peoples Around the World Fought and Built Empires
description: Three new books describe far-flung societies — from the Native tribes of North America to the caliphates of Eurasia — that have made war and sustained their conquests.
content: One of the benefits of studying the military histories of non-European groups is that it reminds us that there are very different means of waging war, as well as reasons for doing so.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Tim Rogers, Hairstylist to the Stars and Moguls, Dies at 51
description: A native of Britain, he made his mark in his adopted city styling celebrities like Adele, Roger Federer and the Olsen twins.
content: Tim Rogers, a sought-after New York hairstylist who fashioned gold-standard looks for a long list of notables, including Adele, Yoko Ono and Roger Federer, and commanded gold-standard prices to match, died on Nov. 3 at his home in Gaylordsville, Conn. He was 51.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Climate Summit Leader Tries to Calm Uproar Over a Remark on Fossil Fuels
description: Sultan Al Jaber, responsible for leading the world away from fossil fuels, had said there was “no science” to support a phaseout of oil and gas.
content: Simmering tensions around the decision to hold a global climate summit in a petrostate burst into the open on Monday when Sultan Al Jaber, the Emirati oil executive who is leading the conference, launched into an angry public defense of his position on ending fossil fuel use.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Ella Fitzgerald, a Voice That Set the American Standard
description: A new biography sheds light on her humble beginnings and prolific, genre-defining career.
content: Ella Fitzgerald was born in 1917 in Newport News, Va.,  but spent most of her childhood in a poor section of Yonkers, N.Y. Her father, a longshoreman, left the family when she was young. Her mother did domestic work, and toiled in a commercial laundry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Love Letter to a Season I Never Loved When I Was Young
description: Darkness falls early now, but I don’t fight it.
content: “It’s the season I often mistake / Birds for leaves, and leaves for birds,” the U.S. Poet Laureate Ada Limón writes of autumn. In fall, a flocking movement in the sky, or in the trees, can mean either kind of marvelous flying thing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: Supreme Court Appears Split Over Opioid Settlement for Purdue Pharma
description: The justices’ questions reflected the tension between the practical effect of unraveling the settlement and broader concerns about whether the Sacklers should be granted such wide-ranging immunity.
content: The Supreme Court justices seemed divided on Monday over a fiercely contested bankruptcy settlement for Purdue Pharma that would funnel billions of dollars into addressing the opioid epidemic in exchange for shielding members of the wealthy Sackler family from related civil lawsuits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: Large Farmers Received Millions in Insurance Subsidies, Report Says
description: A nonpartisan watchdog found that some farmers received more than $3 million in federal crop insurance subsidies and that much of the program’s funds were paid to insurance companies for administrative expenses.
content: The federal government provided millions of dollars in subsidies to large farmers to pay for much of the cost of their crop insurance policies last year, according to a Government Accountability Office report released on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer
title: Brain Implants Helped 5 People Toward Recovery After Traumatic Injuries
description: People with chronic problems after falls and car crashes scored better on cognition tests after getting a brain implant, a new study found.
content: Traumatic brain injuries have left more than five million Americans permanently disabled. They have trouble focusing on even simple tasks and often have to quit jobs or drop out of school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Monday Briefing
description: An evacuation order in southern Gaza.
content: Confusion and fear gripped much of southern Gaza as Israel’s military ordered more residents to clear out, sending people into the streets in desperate search of shelter, two days after a weeklong cease-fire came to an end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle and Jan Hoffman
title: What to Know About the Purdue Pharma Case Before the Supreme Court
description: A federal appeals court had signed off on a deal that would shield members of the wealthy Sackler family from lawsuits in exchange for billions for those harmed by the opioid epidemic.
content: The Supreme Court heard arguments on Monday over a bankruptcy deal for Purdue Pharma that would give billions of dollars to those harmed by the opioid epidemic in exchange for shielding members of the wealthy Sackler family from additional opioid-related lawsuits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Wu
title: The Bigger Airlines Get, the Worse They Become
description: Something to consider as JetBlue seeks to buy Spirit.
content: If there’s one lesson we’ve learned from the recent history of the airline industry, it’s this: The bigger airlines get, the worse they become. The prices get higher, the seats smaller, the service ever snarkier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman and Somini Sengupta
title: Finding Cash for the Climate Is Tough. Two New Pledges Show Why.
description: Money is a very big sticking point at this year’s United Nations climate summit. Part of the problem is that American promises often go unmet.
content: When there’s a global crisis, wealthy countries tend to find money. In the United States, that was the case for the coronavirus pandemic. And for military aid to allies like Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Dec. 4, 2023
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Dec. 4, 2023.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colbi Edmonds
title: Details of Sexual Assault Allegation Against Florida G.O.P. Chair Add to Party Turmoil
description: The details of the allegation against the state party chairman, Christian Ziegler, emerged in an affidavit. He has denied any wrongdoing.
content: Details of a sexual assault allegation against the chairman of the Florida Republican Party in an affidavit from state authorities are fueling turmoil within the party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Goldstein
title: What Costs $1,000 Per Student and Might Help Children Learn to Read?
description: A new study found that California schools got positive results from a targeted investment in the science of reading — even with the challenges of pandemic recovery.
content: To try to make up for pandemic learning loss, educators and policymakers have searched for solutions that work and — just as important — are cost effective.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Balenciaga Basks in the Warm Glow of Celebrity Forgiveness
description: After months of reputational repair, the French house brought its latest show to Los Angeles.
content: Almost exactly a year after setting off a flurry of public opprobrium with a holiday ad campaign that pictured children clutching what looked like B.D.S.M. teddy bears amid other adult paraphernalia — a snowballing crisis that took the company by surprise and sent sales into a nosedive — Balenciaga brought its fall 2024 show to a balmy boulevard in the Hancock Park neighborhood of Los Angeles. On Saturday, it unfurled like a palm tree-and-mansion-lined carpet just under the Hollywood sign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hikari Hida and John Yoon
title: 5 Bodies Found After Days of Searching for U.S. Military Aircraft in Japan
description: The remains of a 24-year-old airman were found last week after the CV-22 Osprey went down during a training exercise. Two other crew members remain unaccounted for.
content: The U.S. Air Force said on Monday that the bodies of five crew members had been found alongside the wreckage of a CV-22 Osprey that went down during a routine training exercise last week in southern Japan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: U.S. Moves to Crack Down on Money Behind Fentanyl Trade
description: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen will travel to Mexico this week for talks on countering illicit finance and fentanyl.
content: The Biden administration said on Monday that it was creating a “counter-fentanyl strike force” within the Treasury Department to combat trafficking of the drug into the United States by more aggressively scrutinizing the finances of suspected narcotics dealers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush, Ernesto Londoño, David C. Adams and Frances Robles
title: Retired U.S. Diplomat Accused of Working as a Secret Agent for Cuba
description: Manuel Rocha, a former ambassador to Bolivia, secretly aided Cuba’s “clandestine intelligence-gathering mission,” U.S. authorities said.
content: Federal prosecutors said on Monday that a retired State Department official worked for decades as a secret agent for Cuba and was heard referring to the United States as “the enemy,” a previously undisclosed intelligence breach with potentially significant diplomatic and national security implications.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee, Iyad Abuheweila and Thomas Fuller
title: Israel, Expanding Offensive, Tells More Gazans to Evacuate
description: As its ground forces prepared to move in the south of Gaza, residents there were told to leave their homes, spreading fear and confusion.
content: Amid a barrage of airstrikes, Israel sharply expanded its evacuation orders in the Gaza Strip on Sunday in preparation for an expected ground invasion in the southern part of the territory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev, Ekaterina Bodyagina, Alina Lobzina, Oleg Matsnev and Gray Beltran
title: A Prison at War: The Convicts Sustaining Putin’s Invasion
description: Nearly 200 inmates left a high-security Russian prison to join the war in Ukraine, seeking redemption, money or freedom. Many were killed or wounded.
content: Aleksandr Mokin had lost the will to live.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: After Shakeup, Trinity Church Appoints Its Next Music Leader
description: Melissa Attebury will be the first woman to run the church’s program, after Julian Wachner was fired last year following accusations of misconduct that he has denied.
content: For more than 20 months, the acclaimed music program at Trinity Church, one of New York’s wealthiest and most powerful churches, has had no permanent leader.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: There Are Politicians Who Lie More Than Is Strictly Necessary
description: In case you were wondering.
content: Gail Collins: Bret, this may sound a bit strange, but I’ve decided to be grateful for all the political debates going on around us. While the real world can get kinda depressing, the debate world is always ready to just chatter away.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Man Who Posed as Federal Agent Is Sentenced to Nearly 3 Years in Prison
description: Arian Taherzadeh befriended Secret Service employees and gave them lavish gifts, including rent-free apartments, to bolster his fraudulent law enforcement business, prosecutors said.
content: A man from Washington, D.C., who pretended to be a federal law enforcement officer and leased luxury apartments for which he failed to pay rent was sentenced to 33 months in prison on Friday, federal authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Dancing With the Stars’ and ‘Murder in Boston’
description: The Mirrorball Trophy will be handed out on the dance competition show, and HBO airs a documentary on a 1989 crime.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Dec. 4-10. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: It Could Be a Vast Source of Clean Energy, Buried Deep Underground
description: In eastern France, and in other places around the world, deposits of natural hydrogen promise bountiful power. But questions remain.
content: In the rocky soil of Lorraine, a former coal mining region near the French-German border, scientists guided a small probe one recent day down a borehole half a mile into the earth’s crust.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amal El-Mohtar
title: The Best Science Fiction and Fantasy of 2023
description: From witch stories to near-future noir, here are the year’s 10 best speculative books.
content: Vajra Chandrasekera’s THE SAINT OF BRIGHT DOORS (Tordotcom, 356 pp., $27.99) is the best book I’ve read this year. Fetter, the protagonist, is one of several almost-chosen-ones who have shirked or sidestepped their spectacular destinies in favor of haunted and marginal lives in the city of Luriat. The city has many “bright doors” that seem to open onto nothing. Fetter’s fascination with them draws him into a web of Luriati intrigue involving his estranged and godlike father, the Perfect and Kind — whom Fetter has been trained since childhood to kill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: 68,000 Gallons of ‘Unfit’ Olive Oil Seized by Italy and Spain
description: Officials in Europe, where a majority of the world’s olive oil is produced, charged 11 people with selling adulterated oil not suitable for consumption.
content: Law enforcement agencies in Spain and Italy have arrested 11 people who ran a “food fraud operation” that produced more than 260,000 liters, or roughly 68,000 gallons, of olive oil that was sold as high-quality but in reality was “unfit for consumption,” officials said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman, Adam Sella and Anat Schwartz
title: What We Know About Sexual Violence During the Oct. 7 Attacks on Israel
description: Israel has accused Hamas of committing abuses against large numbers of women. Hamas denies the allegations.
content: From the first days after the Oct. 7 attacks on Israel, Israel has accused Hamas terrorists of committing widespread sexual violence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Detained in Russia for 250 Days, American Reporter Is Still Awaiting Trial
description: Evan Gershkovich, a journalist for The Wall Street Journal, is being held on a spying charge that he, his newspaper and the U.S. government deny.
content: Monday marked the 250th day that Evan Gershkovich, an American reporter for The Wall Street Journal, has been in custody in Moscow on an espionage charge that he, his newspaper and the U.S. government have vehemently denied, and a lawyer who has worked on similar cases said that Mr. Gershkovich’s time in detention will likely last much longer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: A Logo to Unite America? Good Luck.
description: The design studio behind the U.S. bicentennial emblem was asked to brand America’s 250th anniversary. Per one of its designers, an impossible job called for “an impossible construction.”
content: In an airy conference room high above Manhattan, the designer Sagi Haviv explained the difficulties of creating an elegant logo for the United States’ semiquincentennial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reggie Ugwu
title: Best Podcasts of 2023: Amy Poehler, ‘Heavyweight,’ Willa Paskin
description: The cream of the crop this year includes stalwarts like “Decoder Ring” as well as a new comedy series (Poehler as a gleefully unhinged couples therapist).
content: As always, consider this list not an objective ranking but a kind of tip sheet — more Michelin Guide than the World’s 50 Best Restaurants. These podcasts, presented in alphabetical order, excelled at their missions, whether documenting the impact of national battles on local schools, unpacking internalized fatphobia, or questioning the pedigree of a famed Italian cheese. Casual and avid podcast listeners alike should come away with a clear sense of what the medium can do.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Who Ever Said Magazines Need to Be Ink on Paper?
description: Bowing to financial reality, Bloomberg Businessweek is going monthly.
content: I spent nearly 32 years writing for BusinessWeek and its successor magazine, Bloomberg Businessweek, before joining The Times in 2021. So I was taken aback last week to learn that the weekly I love won’t be a weekly anymore. In a memo to employees, Bloomberg announced that the print magazine will be reintroduced next year as a “premium monthly product.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Antonia Hitchens
title: A Marriage Plot for an Age When Marriage Means Little
description: Naoise Dolan’s “The Happy Couple” follows 20-something Dubliners hurtling toward the altar, stubbornly clinging to their self-delusions that this is what they want.
content: Three years into their relationship, the 20-something Dubliners Celine and Luke still “did not, as a rule, ‘share feelings.’” Celine’s “family never taught her how,” so she measures the partnership by the clutter they’ve accumulated together — it would be so hard to undo. “Marriage will never happen between us,” Luke says to her as they lie in bed after a party. “And that’s not a problem necessarily. It would be silly to stop when it’s going well. But we’re not going to end up together.” One page later, he proposes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: Georgia Republicans Add Majority-Black Congressional District at Expense of McBath
description: If passed, the proposed maps would spur debate over whether majority-minority districts have the same protections against racial discrimination under the Voting Rights Act.
content: Georgia Republicans have proposed new congressional maps that would create an additional majority-Black district in the state while targeting a Democratic congresswoman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: Homeless Advocate Takes On A.C.L.U., and It’s Personal
description: Jennifer Livovich started a nonprofit to give socks to the homeless population in Boulder, Colo. She lost it, and more, in a legal and policy dispute.
content: On the last Thursday of August, Jennifer Livovich spent the morning simmering beans and cheese sauce in her Boulder, Colo., apartment, preparing nachos. Then friends helped her load a truck with the food, along with donations she had secured — socks, toothbrushes, cellphones — to distribute at a downtown park where dozens of chronically homeless people congregate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: U.S. Considers Task Force to Guard Red Sea Ships From Iranian Proxy Forces
description: The discussions come after a U.S. destroyer downed three drones targeting commercial ships on Sunday, part of a series of attacks by the Iranian-backed Houthi militia tied to Israel’s war against Hamas.
content: The United States is in discussions with its allies to set up a naval task force to guard ships traveling through the Red Sea after the latest attack on several commercial vessels in what appears to be an escalating extension of Israel’s war with Hamas by Iranian-sponsored proxy forces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hiba Yazbek, Christoph Koettl and Michael Levenson
title: Israeli Forces Near Major City in Southern Gaza as Civilians Panic
description: Israel, escalating its assault against Hamas in southern Gaza, warned civilians there to evacuate, but some said there was nowhere left to go.
content: Israel widened its military assault against Hamas in the southern part of the Gaza Strip on Monday, with armored vehicles rolling closer to its main city and strikes pummeling urban areas, where images showed smoke rising from flattened buildings and people carrying bodies swaddled in blankets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Security Guard Is Killed in Stabbing at Macy’s in Philadelphia
description: A man was arrested after fleeing the store on the subway, the authorities said. It was unclear what led to the stabbing, in which one other security guard was injured.
content: Two security guards were stabbed on Monday, one of them fatally, at the Macy’s store in Center City Philadelphia by a man who had tried to steal hats from the store, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: That Lingering ‘Meh’ Feeling Has a Name
description: Persistent depressive disorder is underdiagnosed, and many who suffer from it have never heard of it.
content: By the time Amanda Stern was in her mid-40s, she no longer suffered from clinical depression. And her panic attacks, which had started in childhood, were mostly gone. But instead of feeling happier, she said, “I felt wallpapered in an endless, flat sadness.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Guggenheim Lays Off 10 Employees as Museums Face Fiscal Challenges
description: A growing number of museums around the country have raised admission fees and cut staff to try to weather the financial setbacks they have faced since the pandemic began.
content: The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum announced that it had laid off 10 employees in response to a challenging economic moment in the art world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex de Waal and Abdul Mohammed
title: The War the World Forgot
description: The people of Darfur are caught in a battle between Sudanese armies.
content: There’s a genocide in the making in Darfur, Sudan — for the second time in 20 years. This time, the violence is happening on President Biden’s watch, and he and his administration have not done enough to stop it. But there are two things Mr. Biden can do today that could have real impact: Stop America’s Middle Eastern allies from arming the perpetrators and get behind a Kenyan-led African initiative to end the bloodshed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Tyler Goodson of ‘S-Town’ Podcast Is Shot Dead in Police Standoff
description: Mr. Goodson, who had been featured in the investigative podcast set in the town of Woodstock, Ala., “brandished a gun at officers” before he was fatally shot, the authorities said.
content: Tyler Goodson, a key figure in the popular “S-Town” podcast series, died on Sunday after he was shot during a standoff with the police at a house in Woodstock, Ala., southwest of Birmingham, the authorities said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Nikki Haley’s Views on Social Security
description: Readers discuss a column by Paul Krugman. Also: A climate protest at the opera; more Trump coverage?
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech and Rin Hindryati
title: Volcanic Eruption Kills at Least 11 Hikers in Indonesia
description: Dozens of climbers were on Mount Marapi on Sumatra when it began spewing ash, the authorities said. Twelve were still missing.
content: The bodies of 11 hikers were found on the slopes of Mount Marapi on the Indonesian island of Sumatra after a volcanic eruption sent ash plumes cascading down the mountain on Sunday, the local search and rescue agency said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May
title: Agnes Chow, a Hong Kong Activist, Fled to Canada and Isn’t Likely to Return
description: Ms. Chow said she had to make a “patriotic” visit to the mainland to get her passport back. The Hong Kong police condemned her intention to “openly jump bail.”
content: Agnes Chow, a prominent pro-democracy activist in Hong Kong who was arrested as part of a sweeping crackdown, said over the weekend that she had fled to Canada and planned to skip bail, in a bold challenge to the authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: As Winter Approaches, Fears Grow for Homeless Migrants
description: Migrants slept on New York City sidewalks last week. Some advocates worry about what will happen when families need to reapply for shelter after Christmas.
content: With winter ahead, and the influx of migrants continuing unabated, New York City is set to enter a potentially perilous new phase in a crisis that has already overwhelmed homeless shelters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Golembiewski
title: Amber Fossils Suggest Male Mosquitoes Were Once Bloodsuckers
description: The preserved insects, from a cache of Lebanese resin, appear to be male but have mouth parts that are found only on modern female mosquitoes.
content: Every single mosquito that’s ever bitten you has been female. For them, a meal of blood is the ultimate girl dinner. Only females have mouth parts capable of piercing skin. But insects found trapped in amber, described in a study published Monday in the journal Current Biology, suggest that male mosquitoes may have once drunk blood, too.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: How to See California’s Spectacular Monarch Butterflies
description: The insects make an extraordinary migration to the West Coast each winter.
content: The monarch butterflies that come each year to California are, in a word, spellbinding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage, Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman
title: Why a Second Trump Presidency May Be More Radical Than His First
description: Donald Trump has long exhibited authoritarian impulses, but his policy operation is now more sophisticated, and the buffers to check him are weaker.
content: In the spring of 1989, the Chinese Communist Party used tanks and troops to crush a pro-democracy protest in Beijing’s Tiananmen Square. Most of the West, across traditional partisan lines, was aghast at the crackdown that killed at least hundreds of student activists. But one prominent American was impressed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Israel Tells More Gazans to Leave, and Supreme Court to Hear Pharma Case
description: Hear the news in five minutes.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Riley Mellen
title: Militant Rocket Hit Base Linked to Israeli Nuclear Missile Program
description: A Times visual analysis found that a rocket launched from Gaza on Oct. 7 hit an Israeli military base believed to house nuclear-capable missiles, although it’s likely they were not in danger.
content: A rocket most likely fired by Hamas militants during their Oct. 7 attack on Israel struck an Israeli military base where, experts say, many of the country’s nuclear-capable missiles are based, according to a visual analysis of the attack’s aftermath by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Chang Chien and Chris Buckley
title: The Wild Card in Taiwan’s Election: Frustrated Young Voters
description: An important bloc for the governing party, the island’s youth are focusing on bread-and-butter issues and have helped propel the rise of an insurgent party.
content: In the months leading up to a pivotal presidential election for Taiwan, candidates have focused on who can best handle the island democracy’s volatile relationship with China, with its worries about the risks of war. But at a recent forum in Taipei, younger voters instead peppered two of the candidates with questions about everyday issues like rent, telecom scams and the voting age.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: White House Condemns Protest at Israeli Restaurant in Philadelphia
description: Pennsylvania state leaders including Gov. Josh Shapiro also criticized the protest held outside a falafel shop, calling it antisemitic.
content: White House and state officials said that a protest on Sunday was hateful and antisemitic after dozens of pro-Palestinian demonstrators opposed to Israel’s offensive in the Gaza Strip chanted slogans charging “genocide” outside an Israeli-style falafel shop in Philadelphia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adrian Tchaikovsky
title: Attack of the 50-Foot A.I.
description: Is artificial intelligence really on the brink of sapience? Should we be afraid?
content: This personal reflection is part of a series called Turning Points, in which writers explore what critical moments from this year might mean for the year ahead. You can read more by visiting the Turning Points series page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Tuesday Briefing: Israel Expands Operations Across Gaza
description: Plus, kiwis return to Wellington.
content: Israel widened its military campaign against Hamas in southern Gaza yesterday, with armored vehicles rolling closer to its main city and strikes pummeling urban areas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Is It Ever Inappropriate to Wear Red Lipstick?
description: A reader wonders if bold lip color may be overkill in some situations, like job interviews or work parties.
content: There are few cosmetics as charged with meaning as red lipstick, which over the centuries has been associated with female allure, sex, sin, glamour, power and politics. One of the first reported fans of red lipstick was Cleopatra, who was said to have painted her lips with red dye made from crushed carmine beetles. Scarlet women wore scarlet lipstick, but it was also a symbol of the suffragists, who wore it with their white dresses as they marched for the right to vote in the early 1900s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Weinman
title: The Best Crime Novels of 2023
description: Our columnist picks the year’s best.
content: When I made this list, I kept discovering ways in which these books were in conversation with one another. The protagonists of my two favorite mystery series debuts seemed like they could work well together, albeit warily. Several books explored the crimes of serial murderers and gave greater voice to those harmed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson and Tiffany May
title: China Evergrande Gets an Unexpected Reprieve From Liquidation
description: A Hong Kong judge postponed deciding whether to force the breakup of the property developer, which defaulted in 2021 on hundreds of billions of dollars in debt.
content: Once China’s most prolific property developer, China Evergrande has narrowly averted a long-expected liquidation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: 65 Years Later, Brenda Lee’s ‘Christmas Tree’ Hits No. 1
description: “Rockin’ Around the Christmas Tree” beat out Mariah Carey’s “All I Want for Christmas Is You” as the first holiday song to top Billboard’s Hot 100 chart this season.
content: After 65 years, Brenda Lee’s rockabilly holiday chestnut, “Rockin’ Around the Christmas Tree,” has finally made it to No. 1 — and beaten Mariah Carey to it, no less.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: What Slang Do You Use?
description: Gyat, rizz, sigma: Are you up on the latest lingo?
content: Today’s featured article begins:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete McKenzie
title: After Decades of Decline, a Feathered Icon Breeds in New Zealand’s Capital
description: The national bird, the kiwi, has hatched eggs in the wild in the Wellington area for the first time in living memory, thanks to a multiyear conservation effort.
content: At the foot of a towering fern, Pete Kirkman pushed his hand through a curtain of dead branches into a burrow. His fingers settled on a lump of feathers. Gently, he withdrew a fist-sized hatchling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Davis O'Brien and Reid J. Epstein
title: R.F.K. Jr. Allies Say They’ll Spend Over $10 Million on Ballot Access
description: A super PAC backing Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s independent presidential candidacy is leading the costly and legally complex effort, which the Democratic establishment is trying to fight.
content: A super PAC backing the independent presidential candidacy of Robert F. Kennedy Jr. is planning to spend $10 million to $15 million to get Mr. Kennedy on the ballot in 10 states, a substantial effort that, even if partly successful, could heighten Democratic concerns about his potential to play the role of spoiler in 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Talk About Abortion, Don’t Talk About Trump: Governors Give Biden Advice
description: At an annual gathering in Arizona, Democratic governors offered a series of explanations for the president’s political struggles and suggested ideas for selling voters on his re-election.
content: America’s Democratic governors brag about booming local economies, preside over ribbon-cuttings of projects paid for with new federal legislation and have successfully framed themselves as defenders of abortion rights and democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Doug Burgum, Wealthy North Dakota Governor, Ends White House Run
description: The little-known former software executive had hoped his business acumen and relentless focus on the economy, energy and foreign policy would lift his campaign. It didn’t.
content: Gov. Doug Burgum of North Dakota, the wealthy former software executive who entered the presidential campaign in June hoping a back-to-basics appeal on the economy would propel him forward, dropped out of the race for the Republican nomination on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Big Profits in Caring for the Elderly
description: In the U.S., companies seek high profits in the long-term care industry.
content: The United States spends an average of about $13,000 per person every year on health care. No other country comes close to spending so much:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Robert H. Precht, Producer of ‘The Ed Sullivan Show,’ Dies at 93
description: Among the highlights of his long tenure were supervising the Beatles’ appearances and telling the comedian Jackie Mason he was fired.
content: Robert H. Precht, who for more than a decade produced “The Ed Sullivan Show,” the Sunday night variety extravaganza that for 23 years brought singers, comedians, rock bands, jugglers, animal acts and the Italian mouse puppet Topo Gigio into the living rooms of millions of viewers, died on Nov. 26 at his home in Missoula, Mont. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Koeppel
title: Getting Myself Back, One Puzzle at a Time
description: After a devastating injury damaged his cognitive abilities, word games helped the author build new ways to shape his thoughts.
content: “Don’t walk out on the ice,” my wife, a native New Englander, said. “We don’t need the car today.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Can Congestion Pricing Alter New York’s Car Culture?
description: The city has too many cars, especially too many for-hire vehicles, transit experts say.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll look at New York’s congestion pricing plan — what it’s expected to mean for drivers, and whether it goes far enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green, Laura Collins-Hughes, Scott Heller, Naveen Kumar, Juan A. Ramírez and Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Best Theater of 2023
description: Many of the plays and musicals that resonated this year deftly married elements of drama and comedy.
content: If 2023 was a tragedy in the world, on New York stages it was a dramedy year, highlighted not only by serious plays with great jokes, but also by flat-out comedies with dark underpinnings. And though not all 10 shows (and various bonuses) on my mostly chronological list below fit that mongrel category, even the gravest of them seem to have gotten the memo that theater should not be a bore or a drag. It should thrill you into thought or, as the case may be, solace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rachel Quester, Mooj Zadie, Carlos Prieto, Stella Tan, Patricia Willens, Michael Benoist, Marion Lozano, Diane Wong, Dan Powell and Alyssa Moxley
title: The Oct. 7 Warning That Israel Ignored
description: Israel knew about Hamas’s plan more than a year before the attack took place.
content: In the weeks since Hamas carried out its devastating terrorist attack in southern Israel, Times journalists have been trying to work out why the Israeli security services failed to prevent such a huge and deadly assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: At the Kennedy Center, an Ode to the Arts, and a Gentle Jab at Biden’s Age
description: Billy Crystal, Renée Fleming, Queen Latifah, Barry Gibb and Dionne Warwick are honored; Robert De Niro joked that Crystal is just a few years younger than the president.
content: Rarely is the president of the United States, nestled in his box, the center of attention at the Kennedy Center Honors, the annual awards ceremony that brings a carousel of celebrities, musicians and actors to the stage to pay tribute to lifetime achievements in the arts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: inanity
description: This word has appeared in 12 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word inanity has appeared in 12 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Nov. 24 in “France Scoffs at an Englishman’s ‘Napoleon’” by Catherine Porter:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: Why Haley Is Rising Among the Rivals to Trump
description: She has gained with educated and relatively moderate Republicans and independents, but that is also a big liability in today’s G.O.P.
content: If you dozed off while following the Republican primary, I wouldn’t blame you. But it might be worth perking up for a moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Your College Football Team Went Undefeated? Sorry, That’s Not Good Enough.
description: In sports, the best team doesn’t always win a championship, but it almost always gets an opportunity to try. Tell that to the 13-0 Florida State Seminoles.
content: The metaphorical white puffs of smoke sent up by the College Football Playoff selection committee on Sunday signaled that the panel had chosen the four teams that would vie for this season’s championship — and that Florida State, unbeaten champions of the Atlantic Coast Conference, was not among them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca Carballo
title: Myles Goodwyn, Singer-Songwriter of April Wine, Dies at 75
description: Mr. Goodwyn sang and played guitar for April Wine, an arena rock band in the Canadian Music Hall of Fame.
content: Myles Goodwyn, a singer, songwriter and guitarist for the Canadian classic rock group April Wine, died in Halifax, Nova Scotia, on Sunday. He was 75.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cindy Hirschfeld
title: Skiing Hut-to-Hut in Colorado’s Soul-Stirring Backcountry
description: A snowy journey in the San Juan Mountains yields sublime skiing, cozy nights and a serene, nearly spiritual, encounter with nature.
content: “It looks like Canada,” said Nate Disser, our guide, indicating the lofty, snow-cloaked peaks around us. Later that day, when our group of 10 had skied to another high-alpine basin where craggy rock monoliths jutted up from ridgelines, Mr. Disser noted a resemblance to the Italian Dolomites. Yet we were in the San Juan Mountains of southwestern Colorado, a spectacular place in its own right.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erle C. Ellis
title: 1.5 Degrees Is Not the Problem
description: Rich countries must bear responsibility for the climate crisis and help developing nations end their reliance on fossil fuels.
content: As leaders around the world meet for the 28th time to address the climate crisis — this time in the United Arab Emirates, one of the world’s largest oil producers — they need to rethink this threat and some of the other central challenges of our times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Do You Know These Holiday-Time Screen Adaptations?
description: Try this short quiz on movies and television specials that are popular viewing during the holiday season — and the variety of books that originally inspired them.
content: Try this short quiz on movies and television specials that are popular viewing during the holiday season — and the variety of books that originally inspired them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Gazans Say Nowhere Is Safe as Israel Expands Evacuation Orders
description: Many displaced Palestinians have been forced to relocate again as the Israeli military said it is expanding ground operations “all across the Gaza Strip.”
content: Many displaced Palestinians have been forced to relocate again as the Israeli military said it is expanding ground operations “all across the Gaza Strip.”
source.name: The New York Times
